Although the history of China's venture capital (VC) market is relatively short, it has already become the second largest VC market in the world and produced the second largest number of "“unicorns" (startups with a valuation over $\$1$ billion) after the US. Despite the remarkable growth of both China's tech sector and venture capital market, academic research in this area remains sparse. Two broad issues hinder the efforts of researchers studying this market: choosing the right data sources and understanding evolving institutional details. To address these two issues, I first describe available data sources, accompanied with filters aimed at improving the quality of the data. I then review institutional details unique to the Chinese setting and recent regulatory changes that have direct impacts on the Chinese venture capital market. I conclude by listing some openresearchquestions. ## 1. Introduction Although the Chinese venture capital (VC) market has a relatively short history, various estimates suggest that it has already developed into the second largest VC market in the world, falling only behind the US. Additionally, China hosts the second largest number of startups with valuations over $\$1$ billion (commonly referred to as “"unicorns") (Fig. 1). Despite the rapid growth of China's tech sector and venture capital market, there is still relatively little academic research in these areas.? This dearth could be explained, at least in part, by two broad issues. First, like VC research in general, the Chinese VC market lacks consistent and representative data. This issue is exacerbated by the fact that a clear distinction between venture capital and private equity (PE) is lacking in China. Second, though the Chinese VC market shares the basic structures of its US counterpart, some of its institutional settings are dynamic and quickly evolving. The unique nature of these settings raises barriers for researchers studying this market. In this paper, I discuss these two broad issues related to academic research on the Chinese VC market and contribute to the literature by describing available data sources and reviewing relevant institutional details and recent regulatory changes. ![](images/25ce66c243cedd35e2eefc8599b7e27a52670f3347d1abef863cdf5f947b30e6.jpg) Source: CB Insights (as of September 30th, 2021) Fig. 1. For data sources on Chinese venture capital, I list those that have been used in existing research and briefly compare two of the main sources - CVSource and Zero2IPO. Based on my comparison, I rely on the Zero2IPO database - the largest data source covering Chinese venture capital funds - to create the sample used for analysis later in the paper. By applying two main filters to the set of venture capital funds included in the Zero2IPO database, I arrive at a sample of Chinese VC funds that are more likely to actually practice venture capital investing strategies. The first filter requires that the funds be managed by a VC firm. As PE firms in China also raise and manage venture capital funds, this filter separates funds managed by VC firms from other types of asset management firms (like PE) that often have different investing incentives and experience in running the funds. The second filter is the requirement that the funds be registered with a publicly accessible regulatory website similar to the Edgar website in the Us. This filter ensures that the information reported in the commercial database is accurate and that the funds are venture capital funds as opposed to general equity investment funds as disclosed by fund managers. Application of these two filters allows me to derive a clean sample of Chinese venture capital funds whose information is accurate and can be cross-checked. In my discussion of Chinese venture capital institutions, I focus on institutions that are directly related to raising and managing venture capital funds and making investment decisions in China and institutions whose impacts are also more easily quantifiable. Therefore, this discussion is specific and includes relevant regulatory changes in recent years. Specifically, I structure the discussion around the typical “"venture capital cycle": limited partners (LPs) and venture capital funds that together supply the capital, entrepreneurs that demand venture capital, and the exit of VC investments from portfolio companies. In the discussion of the supply of venture capital, I first discuss Chinese government guidance funds. I then focus on the set of more standard and market-driven Chinese venture capital funds. For this set of funds, I describe the current composition of limited partners (LPs) and also discuss recent regulatory changes that could alter this composition in the long run. These changes include relaxations on existing rules that prohibit public institutions from making equity investments. For venture capital funds, my discussion focuses on organization forms and on a legal change in 2007 that made limited partnership available in China for venture capital funds. In the discussion of the demand for venture capital, I explain some of the factors and regulatory changes that may have played an important role in promoting the rise of entrepreneurship in China, particularly high-tech entrepreneurship. Lastly, I describe the current distribution of exit channels for Chinese VCs and document how the launch of recent stock exchanges has further facilitated the IPO channel as the dominant exit route for Chinese venture capital funds. While this paper focuses on data sources and institutional details for Chinese venture capital research, it does not provide a complete survey of existing academic research on the Chinese VC market, nor does it try to characterize venture capital investments in China.3 For information on the funding of entrepreneurship and innovation in China, Cong et al. 2020) provide a survey of academic findings and discuss the implications for public policy. For characteristics of Chinese venture capital investments, Huang and Tian (2020) provide a recent review.4 There also exists a broader view of institutions that can impact venture capital, including political structure, property rights, culture, and social norms. While this broader institutional view is not within the scope of this paper, Bruton and Ahlstrom (2003) provide relevant discussion of these topics. The paper is organized as follows: in Section 2, I describe the available data sources for Chinese venture capital research. In Sections 3 and 4, I focus on the supply and demand side of Chinese venture capital, respectively. In Section 5, I examine the exit channels for Chinese VCs. I conclude in Section 6 by listing some open questions. ## 2. Data sources As is the case for research on the US VC market (Kaplan and Lerner, 2016), a universal venture capital database for the Chinese VC market does not exist. Table 1 summarizes a list of data sources that have been used in the academic research on the Chinese venture capital market. Within this list, CVSource (or ChinaVenture, https://www.cvsource.com.cn/) and Zero2IPO (or PEdata, http://www. zero2ipo.com.cn/en/) are the two most commonly used databases (see, e.g., Gu and Lu, 2014; Fu et al., 2019; Suchard et al., 2021). A few reasons may explain the wide use of CVSource and Zero2IPO. First, these two databases are the earliest to start tracking Chinese VC investments and, therefore, are likely more comprehensive in covering data from earlier periods relative to newer data sets, such as CNRDS. Zero2IPO, in particular, was founded in 2000, which marks the beginning of the Chinese VC industry. Second, based in China, these two databases are likely better at collecting local VC activity in comparison to databases operating outside of China, e.g. VentureXpert and Pitchbook.5 Third, because CVSource and Zero2IPO are specialized venture capital databases, they likely cover a more representative sample of venture capital investments in comparison to databases that are better known for covering Chinese public firms, such as CSMAR and WIND.° Lastly, as commercial databases, CVSource and Zero2IPO may have a stronger incentive to collect and maintain high quality venture capital data relative to the public disclosure data provided by AMAC and NECIPS where only basic information is available. The existence of multiple datasets, as well as their use without careful comparison and specification of filters for sample selection, risks producing inconsistent and unreliable research results. Therefore, I focus on the two most commonly used databases, CVSource and Zero2IPO, and begin by comparing them. As most of my discussion in this paper is based on a sample of venture capital funds, 1 compare the two datasets based on the set of venture capital funds they cover. To compare the two databases, I first download all venture capital funds that are closed between 2000 and 2020 from each of the databases. Specifically, for CVSource I select the fund type “venture" in the fund table, and for Zero2IPO I select “venture capital funds."' I then merge the two sets of funds based on their full legal name without applying any filters.7 Examining the merged datasets, I find the following: First, the two databases vary significantly in their coverage, with a large fraction of the data non-overlapping. For example,fewerthan $40\%$ of the funds covered by CVSource appear in Zero2IPO, while fewer than $10\%$ of thefundscoveredby Zero2IPO appear in CVSource. Second, Zero2IPO covers many more VC funds than CVSource. For example, over the sample period 2000-2020, the former database covers 11,302 funds, while the latter only covers 2474 funds.8 As Zero2IPO provides a much larger sample of venture capital funds than CVSource, I use Zero2IPO as the main source for the analysis in this paper and CVSource as an alternative source to provide robustness checks whenever possible.9 One issue present in the Chinese VC data is that a clear boundary between venture capital and private equity is lacking (Huang and Tian, 2020). In fact, both Chinese VC firms and PE firms raise so-called “venture capital funds" that may be used to invest in startups. Among the venture capital funds that are included in the Zero21PO database, I find that 5276 are raised by VC firms and 5026 are raised by PE firms. As shown in Fig. 2, the fundraising activity of PE firms is much more volatile than that of VC firms, especially in recent years. This wide fluctuation of PE activities indicates that these firms are more subject to market cycles and operate much differently than traditional VCs. In addition, I find that on average a PE firm raises about $30\%$ fewer venture capital funds than a VC firm and is thus less experienced. Consistent with PE's inexperience in startup investing, I find that PE-managed funds have a lower success rate than VC-managed funds, and the latter produced three times as many successful exits as the former fund type over the period 2000-2020. The plot is by fund closing year over the 2000-2020 period. Another issue with the Chinese VC data is that venture capital funds were not subject to any public disclosure before 2014. Without such disclosure, the authenticity and accuracy of the information in the VC database is difficult to verify.11 As of 2014, a regulatory change began requiring all domestic VC firms, together with the funds they managed (including both active and liquidated funds), to register with a self-regulatory association of asset management companies (i.e., Asset Management Association of China, or AMAC) on AMAC's publicly accessible website (https://gs.amac.org.cn/amac-infodisc/res/pof/manager/index.html).12 Registration with AMAC is not only required by the law, it is also a prerequisite for VC firms to apply for tax benefits and enjoy other regulatory advantages.13 As shown by Fig. 3, Chinese VC funds have largely been complying with the registration requirement.14 For VC funds that are closed after 2012, the fraction of funds that registered with AMAC is above $60\%$ and has increased to almost $90\%$ in more recent years. This required registration with AMAC facilitates data collection and improves the quality of Chinese VC data in several ways. First, it allows data providers to verify their data; extract more accurate information, including the full legal name and social IDs of asset managers and their funds; and link this information to other publicly available data sources, such as business registration data. This will ultimately improve the accuracy and coverage of Chinese VC data. Second, the registration of VC funds with AMAC also requires disclosing the fund type: as either a venture capital fund or a general equity investment fund. Since a qualified venture capital fund must mainly invest in small and young firms that have potential for high growth, this disclosure is useful in clearly separating VC funds from other types based on legal compliance.15 For these reasons, I restrict the sample of VC funds in the Zero2IPO database to those whose registration with AMAC can be verified by the data provider and those that have disclosed themselves as “venture capital funds" in the registration. In summary, starting with 11,302 venture capital funds in the Zero2IPO database that are closed between 2000 and 2020,16 1 require thesefundstobe 1.China-based(excluding389funds), 2. managed by VC firms (excluding 5637 funds),17 and 3. registered with AMAC as “venture capital funds” (excluding 2100 funds) As a result of these requirements, I derive a sample of 3176 Chinese VC funds, which is the main sample for my analysis in this paper.18 Although it is easier to apply the above filters to Chinese venture capital funds based on the Zero2IPO database, it is also feasible to do so using other data sources. For reasons discussed above, these filters will likely produce a cleaner and more reliable sample for Chinese venture capital research. Depending on the specifics of the settings, however, caution should be exercised when applying these filters. For example, the filter that excludes funds managed by PE firms from our main sample could underestimate the total market size of startup financing available in China; this filter could also introduce bias for the analysis of late-stage financing deals as PE-managed funds are more likely to invest in late-stage deals compared to VC-managed funds.19 Secondly, the filter that requires AMAC registration of venture capital funds excludes funds from earlier periods and funds managed by foreign VCs from our main sample.2° This exclusion may limit analysis of a broader sample of VCs operating in China over a longer period. Finally, Chinese venture capital data can be relatively easily matched to external data sets, including public firms, business registration, and patent data. For example, both CVSource and Zero2IPO provide full legal names of venture capital funds and their portfolio companies. As both VC funds and portfolio companies are required to have a unique full legal entity name to operate (e.g., Fei, 2018), they can be accurately matched to external data sets based on these full legal names.21 Beyond full legal names, VC databases may also provide information on uniform social credit codes for venture capital funds and portfolio companies, which is a mandatory and permanent legal identifier for any business entity operating in China.22 This uniform social credit code can further facilitate the matching of Chinese venture capital data with external data sets.23 ![](images/983268c673869797642fe883e48e0634195155c64d496d72b991189275c532a6.jpg) Fig. 3. The supply of venture capital I start my discussion of the institutional details of the Chinese VC market from the supply side of venture capital. Specifically, I first discuss Chinese government guidance funds (GGFs) in Subsection 3.1. I then focus on the set of non-GGF venture capital funds in our main sample, which are more standard and market driven. Specifically, for this set of VC funds, I discuss the composition of limited partners (LPs) in Subsection 3.2 and the organization forms of the venture capital funds in Subsection 3.3. ### 3.1. Government guidance funds A special type of fund that plays an important role in the Chinese VC market is government guidance funds (GGFs). GGFs are policy funds set up by Chinese governments at various levels to provide funding for firms in sectors that central or local governments consider important and under-funded. GGFs also serve the goal of encouraging other sources of capital to further invest in these sectors. Depending on the specific focus, a GGF can be either a government-oriented industry guidance fund or a VC investment guidance fund.24 Similar to non-GGF venture capital funds, a GGF can be organized as a Limited Liability Company (LLC), or a Limited Partnership (LP) (see more discussion in Subsection 3.3 below). The first GGF - the Zhongguancun VC guidance fund - was established in Beijing in 2002. Since then, GGFs in China have seen significant growth (see Fig. 4). Estimates based on the Zero2IPO database suggest that 1631 GGFs with a total target size of 9.0 trillion ![](images/1116945ff6efcd4f901b43affe04ba74835c819d544319378a646a6efd15d7ce.jpg) Fig. 4.Government Guidance Funds. Notes: The upper panel of this figure plots the number of all Chinese government guidance funds (GGFs) and the number of GGFs managed by stateowned firms by year. The lower panel plots the distribution of commitment events by investor type for the set of GGFs whose investors can be identified. RMB(about $\$1.3$ trillion) have been raised over the period of 2002-2020.25 The number of GGFs is particularly significant in comparison to the 3176 funds raised by VC firms in our main sample.26 As noted above, GGFs can be set up either by the central government or by local governments at the provincial, prefectural city, and county levels. Based on the Zero2IPO sample of GGFs, only a tiny fraction of GGFs $(2.21\%)$ are set up by the central government, and the vast majority are set up by local governments.27 The investment capital for GGFs may be provided solely by governments through public budget or jointly by governments and other sources of capital. Although GGFs encourage commitments from various types of investors, including private investors, the data suggestthatover $80\%$ of investors are still state-owned. For a set of GGFs whose investor types can be identified (about $60\%$ ofallGGF investors), we further decompose the investors by type. The lower panel of Fig. 4 shows that the investor distribution of GGFs is dramatically different from that of non-GGF venture capital funds (see Subsection 3.2 below). Since GGFs are directly set up by central and local governments, the development of GGFs is heavily impacted by government policies and regulations. Since 2007, a series of GGF regulations have been published by the agencies overseeing GGFs, including the Ministry of Finance (MOF) and the National Development and Reform Commission (NDRC). Together with the Ministry of Science and Technology, the MOF first published a rule in 2007 that specifies the framework for administering Technology-SME-oriented VC investment guidance funds.28 Then in 2015, the MOF released another notification that provides guidelines for the administration of so-called “state-investment funds.\*29 Further in 2016, the NDRC released its own rule regarding the administration of industry guidance funds with government ownership.30 Although these regulations from various oversight agencies have slightly different policy foci, they all govern the establishment and operation of GGFs in China. Together with some strong policy initiatives around 2015,31 these regulations almost immediately stimulated a surge of GGFs in China (Fig. 4). For example, more than 400 GGFs were established in 2016 alone. The number of newly founded GGFs has fallen since the 2016 peak, but it remains significant at around 100 funds each year. While a potentially important source of capital for Chinese startups, GFs still have a relatively short history, and their continued development faces a set of obstacles. For example, even though the 2015 and 2016 regulations clearly state that GGFs should be operated on market principles and managed by professional firms, estimates based on the Zero2IpO sample suggest that about $75\%$ Oof all GGFs are still managed by state-owned firms, which raises questions over whether the best management firms have been selected for GGFs. Furthermore, although the regulations prohibit governments from interfering with the daily operations of GGFs, many local governments still frequently require mandatory funding of certain sectors or companies to promote local economy (Lin, 2021). Finally, GGFs may also suffer from governance issues, e.g., appointing managers instead of selecting those most capable based on their track record. Given these obstacles, along with GGFs departure from standard venture capital funds in practice, I exclude GGFs from the main sample in this paper. The remainder of my discussion focuses on the sample of Chinese VC funds that are more market driven and resemble their international counterparts. ### 3.2. The composition of limited partners For each VC fund, the Zero2IPO database provides information on the number of LPs of each type. Using the main sample of Chinese VC funds constructed in Section 2, I compute the fraction of capital commitment events from each type of LP to gauge the relative importance of different types of LPs in the Chinese VC market.32 Fig. 5 plots the fraction and shows that the most important LP class in the Chinese VC market is “"wealthy families and individuals,”’ which represent about $60\%$ of the market share by number of commitment events. According to Chinese regulations, these LPs must be “qualified investors" that have net assets of at least 10 million RMB (about $\$1.6$ million) as institutions or that have financial assets of 3 million RMB (about $\$0.5$ million) or annual income of 500,000 RMB (about $\$80,000$ in the last three years as individuals.3 The second most important LP class is \*VC/PE investment institutions,” which account for about $20\%$ of the market share. These are unspecified institutional investors that make asset allocations to the VC/PE asset class. The third largest LP class is “enterprises,” which contribute about $10\%$ of the commitments. These LPs are for-profit companies, either state-owned or privately-owned businesses that make contributions to VC funds. Among the set of VC funds with at least one enterprise LP, I find that for about $11\%$ of the funds, the enterprise is the only LP. Enterprise LPs of this type are also considered to be corporate VCs (i.e., CVCs) (Ma, 2020), which play an important role in financing startups. The other types of LP classes account for less than $10\%$ in market share as each single group. 34 ![](images/c86aee0ceeeb1c36bed49f91a683409f21d96ba3f19410090797a6fe2ecfe319.jpg) Fig. 5. Fraction of Commitment Events by LP Type. Notes: This figure plots the distribution of commitment events by LP type for the main sample of Chinese venture capital funds in this paper. Each LI investing in a VC fund is counted as one commitment event. As shown in Fig. 5, the composition of LPs in the Chinese VC market is dramatically different from that of the US VC market. For example, while the largest LP class in China - wealthy families and individuals - represents as much as $60\%$ of the market share, the same group of LPs accounts for less than $1\%$ in the Us.35 At the same time, important institutional investors, such as public pension funds and university endowments, each contributing about $30\%$ of the LP market share in the US VC market, are not significant players in China (Lerner et al., 2007). As different types of LP investors have different risk appetite and liquidity demand and are subject to different industry dynamics and economic cycles, differences in the profile of LP investors between the China and US VC markets could have unique implications for the evolution of the Chinese VC market. For quite some time, large and public institutions such as pension funds and banks had not been allowed to invest in the Chinese equity market. However, the experience of other countries suggests that the participation of large and sophisticated institutional investors in a country's equity market can be very valuable. These investors not only have the capacity to supply long-term and large amounts of capital, but they can also stabilize the equity market as they are often less speculative and focused on the long-term value of investments. Additionally, the participation of large institutional investors in the equity market, such as university endowments, can make higher returns for the investors themselves and increase their ability to pay their own obligations. Perhaps having realized the value of large institutional investors' participation in the equity market, in recent years Chinese regulators have started to make policy changes to relax existing restrictions. In particular, a rule was passed in 2015 to allow public pension funds held by local governments to make equity investments of up to $30\%$ of their net assets (Table 2).36 Due to a set of organizational frictions, the implementation of the 2015 rule is still on-going. In the long run, given the scale of public pension funds,37 the rule change could allow public pension funds to become a significant source of capital for the VC market. A similar regulatory change also occurred in the insurance industry. In December 2014, the China Insurance Regulatory Com. mission issued a notification that allows insurance companies to invest as much as $2\%$ of their total assets in VC funds.38 The rule was further updated in 2018, which confirmed insurance companies' eligibility for investing in venture capital funds.39 Overall, there seems to be a trend that more and more public Chinese institutions will be allowed to make equity investments and participate in the venture capital market. This will ultimately change the composition of LPs in this market, potentially reducing the role of individual and family LPs and increasing the significance of institutional LPs. How this change will impact the supply of venture capital and the development of the Chinese VC market remains an open question. ### 3.3. The organization form of venture capital funds Similar to their US counterparts, Chinese venture capital funds are also organized as limited-life and close-ended funds.40 In this subsection, I focus my discussion on the organization forms of Chinese venture capital funds, as these forms have direct implications for the incentives of LPs and venture capitalists, and on the management and allocation of venture capital. Before a regulatory change in 2006, the only legal structures available for Chinese VC funds were the Limited Liability Company (LLC), Joint Stock Company, and General Partnership. Among these structures, a vast majority of the VC funds used the LLC organizationtype, which accounted for $98\%$ of the VC funds. The remaining $2\%$ of VC funds were organized as joint stock companies since the number of investors in the funds may have exceeded the legal limit of 50 for a LLC company. In 2007, following the passage of the Partnership Enterprise Law (PEL),41 a new organization form - limited partnership - became available for Chinese venture capital funds. Similar to its US counterpart, limited partnership in China is a pass-through entity and does not pay tax on its own, and thus does not suffer from the double taxation problem like other Chinese organization entities such as LLCs ![](images/1dd54741732f20912a56ea6540bc2acccf1dc0c0b854732e80d21f57d04e1ffd.jpg) Fig. 6. The vertical line represents the year 2007, the first year in which the limited partnership form became available in China. and joint stock companies.42 I plot the fraction of VC funds that are organized as limited partnerships by fund closing year in Fig. 6. Several patterns emerge from the plot. First, the limited partnership form has already become the most popular organization type for Chinese venture capital funds. For example, after 2011, more than $60\%$ of the new VC funds closed in each year have been organized as limited partnerships. In more recent years, the fraction of new VC funds organized as limited partnerships has reached almost $100\%$ .Second, the adoption of the limited partnership form had a slow start before 2011. This slow adoption is at least partly due to a legal obstacle: a limited partnership firm was not allowed to open a security account with any Chinese securities-registration-and-clearing institution (ultimately important for exit if any of the invested portfolio companies goes public) since limited partnership is not considered a “legal person” by Chinese laws. The problem was solved toward the end of 2009 as the China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) specifically changed the security account rule for limited partnerships.43 As demonstrated by Fig. 6, the removal of the legal obstacle has had a large impact on the adoption of the limited partnership form by Chinese VC funds. Unlike its more recent adoption by venture capital funds in China, limited partnership has long been the dominant form of organizing venture capital funds in the US since the early 1980s (Gompers and Lerner, 1996). Existing literature has argued that the limited partnership form is an optimal organization structure for making venture capital investments because it enables large institutional investors to inject significant sums of capital and to serve as LPs, while also allowing seasoned and specialized asset managers to draw on their experience and expertise in managing the capital as GPs (e.g., Rosenberg, 2002; Kenney, 2000). Consistent with this idea, we indeed observe that limited partnership has long served as the dominant organization form for VC funds in the US and has quickly become the most commonly used form for VC funds in China after it became available. This also suggests that the limited partnership form appears to be an important financial instrument for raising and allocating venture capital across a spectrum of political environments and social norms. Still, micro-level evidence is sparse regarding how the limited partnership form impacts the incentives of LPs and GPs and the investment decisions of venture capitalists. The 2007 legal change in China potentially provides an ideal setting to study this question for two reasons. First, the change is more recent, and second, the LLC form can serve as a more natural and appropriate comparison group for limited partnerships. I leave this open question for future research. ## 4. The demand for venture capital In this section, I discuss some of the demand side factors that are important for the development of the Chinese venture capital market. It is known that venture capital finances high-tech and high-growth entrepreneurship that typically carries tremendous risk and uncertainty. Therefore, to have a prosperous venture capital market, enough talented and skilled entrepreneurs must be willing to take on this risk and form VC-investable businesses. A few factors in the Chinese system may have played an important role in supplying these entrepreneurs. First, initiated by the policy of “reform and openness" in 1978, the Chinese economy has become increasingly liberated and capitalistic. As a result, the huge market has created countless opportunities for brave entrepreneurs. Atracted by these opportunities, the Chinese society as a whole has become highly entrepreneurial. For example, as of July 2021, there are about 146 million active busines entities operating in China. 4 The prosperity of entrepreneurship in the Chinese population naturally creates entrepreneurship that is investablebyVCs. A second policy change that may have unintentionally increased the supply of Chinese entrepreneurs is the expansion of university recruitment beginning in 1999.45 The policy change is significant. Before the change, university recruitment grew at about $8.5\%$ annually. After the change, the growth rate reached almost $50\%$ in 1999, remaining at relatively high rates for another decade until 2012. At the end of the university recruitment expansion, the gross enrollment rate in China reached about $35\%$ .The1999 education policy change increased the supply of high-tech entrepreneurs in China for two reasons. First, the change directly increased the number of well-educated individuals who are better prepared to start high-tech entrepreneurship.46 Second, the policy dramatically increased labor market competition for new graduates to take jobs in existing firms and sectors, which facilitated the choice of some students into entrepreneurship upon graduation.47 A third factor that may have also been important for Chinese high-tech entrepreneurship is the increasing supply of so-called "returnee” entrepreneurs. These are the entrepreneurs who have studied or worked overseas and eventually come back to start businesses in China. One example is Robin Li, who both studied and worked in the US for many years before he returned to China and co-founded one of the largest Chinese tech giants, Baidu, in 2000. To provide more quantitative evidence, I retrieve top management data of Chinese public firms from the CNRDS database and examine the founders overseas experience.48 I define a founder of a public firm as either the CEO or chairman of the board who held their positions before the firm went public. Focusing on the sample of public firms that had their IPOs between 2000 and 2020, I find that a significant fraction of the founders in the high-tech sectors are returnees. For example, as much as $14\%$ of all founders in the Biotechnology sector are returnees, and more than $10\%$ in the IT sector are returnees (Fig. 7). Examining the fraction of returnee founders over time, the lower panel of Fig. 7 suggests that there is also an increasing supply of returnee entrepreneurs in China in more recent years. To attract highly skilled emigrants back to their local regions, many Chinese local governments have also adopted returnee-friendly policies, including tax breaks, subsidized housing, local grants, and awards for returnees.49 Some academic studies suggest that these policies have produced positive impacts on improving local corporate governance and fostering entrepreneurial activity (e.g., Zweig, 2006; Giannetti et al.,2015). Finally, entrepreneurship itself may also respond to available financial or economic resources, and therefore, some factors on the financing side beyond those discussed in Section 3 may also play an important role in promoting entrepreneurship in China. For example, Allen et al. (2005) have argued that reputation- and relationship-based informal finance is important for the growth of the private sector in China. Informal finance includes funding from founders' family and friends, private credit agencies, investments from "ethnic Chinese" (investors from Hong Kong, Taiwan, and overseas Chinese), and trade credits. These informal financing channels may be particularly important in supporting entrepreneurship when formal financial and legal systems are under-developed as is the case in China (Porta et al., 1998). Another financing side factor that may have also been important for Chinese entrepreneurs is household equity. For example, Wang (2012) shows that following a 1994 reform that allowed state employees to purchase their rental homes at subsidized prices, entrepreneurship increased in Urban China. She also finds evidence that this increase in entrepreneurship is driven by the reduction in labor mobility costs and alleviation of credit constraints following the reform. The household equity channel may have been a particularly important factor in China given that China has the highest home ownership rate in the world (e.g., Huang et al., 2021). Some other financing side factors may have also played an important role for Chinese entrepreneurship. For example, foreign direct investment (FD1) is an important source of capital for Chinese entrepreneurs (e.g., Allen et al., 2005), and China remains the top destination for FDI in the world.5o ![](images/3b8615267f434b26772e0c63329d411e63be1b8c229a5d627d5f931783f44f57.jpg) Fig. 7. Returnee Founders of Chinese Public Firms. Notes: The upper panel of this figure plots the fraction of returnee founders over allfounders of Chinese public firms by industry. The lower panel plots the number of IPOs and the fraction of IPOs with at least one returnee founder by IPO year. In sum, the set of unique factors discussed above may have contributed to entrepreneurship in China, particularly high-tech entrepreneurship. Without systematic studies, the exact impact and relative importance of each factor is still not well understood and warrants future research in these areas. Finally, more recent policy initiatives, such as the Mass Entrepreneurship and Innovation ![](images/6ec642b12c82f4d123f4ccfdfdd0149aa543a26b229b1e7aa52a00527b23acb1.jpg) Fig. 8. The lower panel plots the capital value in billions of US dollars that is returned to the Chinese VC funds in these exits by different exit types. Program, may also affect the supply of entrepreneurs in China, the impacts of which could be tested in the future.51 ## 5. The VC exit In this section, I discuss the exit channels for Chinese VCs. Having accessible exit channels is crucial for the healthy development of a venture capital market as VCs need to exit from their portfolio holdings after years of illiquid investments, return the capital to their LPs, and then raise new funds. I examine the exit channels based on the main sample of Chinese VC funds retrieved from the Zero2IPO database. Among the portfolio companies invested by these funds, the upper panel of Fig. 8 reports the number of venture-backed companies that have gone through each type of exit. The numbers suggest that there are four types of exit for Chinese VC funds. The IPO channel is the most important, accounting for almost $60\%$ of the exits. The second most important exit channel is the M&A route, which accounts for $22\%$ The third channel is secondary sale, accounting for $16\%$ of the exits. These are sales of equity stakes of the portfolio companies to other institutional or individual investors. The last channel is management buyout, which accounts for less than $4\%$ of the exits. The lower panel of Fig. 8 reports the total dollar value of each type of exit received by Chinese VC funds. The rank of the four exit channels based on their importance remains unchanged. However, the lower panel also reveals that in terms of capital returned to VC investors, the IPO and M&A channels play a much more important role than the other two exit channels. For example, the IPO and M&A channels returned almost 13 times more capital to VC investors compared to the secondary sale and management buyout channels. This finding is also consistent with the pattern found in other countries that IPOs and M&As are the two main channels of exit for VCs. Focusing on IPO and M&A exits, we notice a dramatic difference between the US and China VC market. While IPO has traditionally provided the largest source of revenue for US VCs, M&A has accounted for the vast majority of venture-backed exits by number in recent years. For example, although the US had a strong IPO environment in 2018, the share of all venture-backed exits via IPO versus M&A is only $11\%$ in the Us.52 In contrast, as demonstrated by Fig. 8, IPO is a much more important exit channel for Chinese VCs, providing almost 3 times as many exits as M&A and returning almost 4 times as much capital as M&A. The difference between the US and China VC markets in IPO versus M&A exit channels reflects some differences in the environment and frictions in the two markets conducting each type of exit. For example, conducting an M&A transaction in China typically requires regulatory approval, which could increase the uncertainty of the deal. In addition, debt financing for M&As in China is also restricted.53 Because the IPO exit channel serves as the most important exit channel for Chinese VC funds, I examine it in more detail. The upper panel of Fig. 9 plots the number of venture-backed IPOs by stock exchange. Several patterns emerge. First, the vast majority of IPO exits for Chinese VC funds went through the domestic stock exchanges. For example, the number of IPOs that went through the four domestic stock exchanges (Shenzhen ChiNext, Shanghai Main, Shanghai Star, and Shenzhen Main) is 15 times as many as those that went through overseas stock exchanges. This difference is in contrast to foreign VCs that operate in China, which typically rely on overseas IPOs much more heavily (Huang and Tian, 2020). Second, among the domestic stock exchanges providing IPO exits, the two newer stock exchanges (Shenzhen ChiNext and Shanghai Star) specifically established to improve IPO exit for high-tech companies are more important exit channels for Chinese venture-backed companies than the two traditional stock exchanges (Shenzhen Main and Shanghai Main).54 For example,the former two stock exchanges contributed about $55\%$ of all domestic VCs IPO exits, while the latter two only contributed about $39\%$ The main boards of the Shenzhen and Shanghai stock exchanges (Shenzhen Main and Shanghai Main) were established in 1990 as the first two stock exchanges in mainland China. While they still serve as important exit channels for Chinese VC-backed companies, they also place more stringent requirements on the companies going public in terms of firm assets, profitability, and other conditions. As it often takes longer for high-tech companies to generate profits, especially those backed by VCs, the more stringent requirements makes getting listed on the two traditional Chinese stock exchanges more difficult for VC-backed companies. To solve these problems, the Chinese government has launched a number of new stock exchanges over the years. Shenzhen ChiNext was established in 2009, and since its launch, it has become the most important exit channel for domestic VCbacked companies. For example, Shenzhen ChiNext alone has contributed approximately $35\%$ of all domestic VCs IPO exits. A recent study by Bernstein et al. (2020) also finds that the ChiNext stock exchange has been a successful experiment on improving entrepreneurial firms access to the public capital market. Touted as China's equivalent to the US Nasdaq, another new board - Shanghai Star - was established in 2019 with the objective of giving Chinese science and technology companies greater access to capital markets.5 As shown by the lower panel of Fig. 9, the Shanghai Star almost immediately became the most important IPO channel for Chinese VCbacked companies after its launch. Overall, Fig. 9 shows that while Chinese VCs rely on domestic stock exchanges for IPO exits, they also rely more heavily on the newer stock exchanges that have lower listing criteria. This suggests that domestic VC-backed companies were constrained in the IPO exit channel before the newer stock exchanges were established. This is somewhat unsurprising given that the traditional Chinese stock exchanges have stringent requirements and the approval-based system often makes the go-public process lengthy and highly uncertain. As the newer stock exchanges were introduced over the years, the constraints in the IPO exit channels for domestic VC-backed companies have been gradually relieved. To further improve capital market access for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) ![](images/c86395e65389aca630ce32058a1843d1c02044e5667fa1c66494072101545298.jpg) Fig. 9. IPO by Stock Exchange. The lower panel plots the number of IPOs by IPO year for IPOs on different stock exchanges. The vertical lines represent 2009 and 2019, the years in which Shenzhen ChiNext and Shanghai Star boards were launched, respectively. in China, the Chinese government launched another new stock exchange in Beijing in 2021.56 As the IPO exit channel has become more accessible for Chinese VC-backed companies, it is likely that the IPO exit channel will continue to serve as the dominant route for Chinese VCs exiting their investments.57 Indeed, as shown by Fig. 10, the dominance of the J. Notes: This figure plots the number of IPOs and M&As backed by the Chinese VC funds in the main sample by exit year. IPO channel over M&A has become even more prominent in recent years, especially after the launch of the Shanghai Star board. The improvement of the IPO exit for Chinese VCs will also likely impact how they raise and manage funds and make investments. Though the overall impact of this improvement on the development of the Chinese VC market is expected to be positive, micro-level evidence remains scant thus far. Future research could rely on the launch of the new stock exchanges, such as Shenzhen ChiNext and Shanghai Star, for exogenous variation and provide more insight into these areas.58 ## 6. Concluding discussions In this paper, I have chosen to discuss the institutional details of the Chinese venture capital market that are more recent and easily quantifiable and that impact the Chinese VC market more directly, either from the supply or demand side of venture capital or through exit channels. Given this choice, I have left out other potentially important regulations for Chinese VCs, e.g., the Torch program in the 1980s,59 the Innofund in the 1990s, and the split-share structure reform in 2005. Due to a lack of data, this paper also skipped the discussion of venture capital contracts in the Chinese setting.6o As evidenced from the discussions in this paper, the development of the Chinese VC market is heavily influenced by the Chinese government, either through regulations like those discussed in the paper or through direct actions such as running government guidance funds competing with VCs or contributing capital to VC funds as LPs.61 Additionally, taxation is also often used as an important policy tool. For example, the Chinese government made tax policy changes in 2017 and 2018 that allow VC investors to deduct $70\%$ of the invested capital from their taxable income earned from their investments.62 Moving forward, the Chinese government at various levels will likely continue to play an important role in the development of the Chinese VC market and keep shaping its direction. In summary, I have both described the datasets available for research on the Chinese VC market and discussed institutional details relevant to the market. The quality of the datasets will likely continue to improve and become more reliable over time as public disclosure by Chinese VC funds increases. In terms of institutional details, it is evident that the Chinese VC market provides fertile ground for researchers to test various economic theories and empirical predictions. It should be also clear that more research is warranted on the Chinese VC market as it has grown to be the second largest in the world. The materials in this paper may serve as a first step toward these future efforts. I conclude by listing a handful of open research questions motivated by my discussion: · What is the impact of the limited partnership organization form on the fundraising, managing, and investing of venture capital funds? · What are the key determinants of Chinese entrepreneurship, especially high-tech entrepreneurship? · How does the improvement of the IPO exit channel impact venture capitalists' fundraising and investments? Specifically, what are the impacts of the launch of the Shenzhen ChiNext board in 2009 and the Shanghai Star board in 2019? ## References Ahlstrom, D., Bruton, G.D., Yeh, K.S., 2007. # scientific data OPEN DATA DESCRIPTOR # A dataset of venture capitalist types in China (1978-2021): A machine-human hybrid approach Jin Chen, Ruining Cao, Yifei Song1, Anan Hu $\textcircled{\textcircled{1}}^{2\bigstar}$ & Ying Ding1 Despite escalating interest in distinguishing among various types of venture capitalists (VCs) and their roles in shaping entrepreneurship and innovation, such research remains sparse in the world's secondlargest VC market, i.e., China. To address this important gap, we have devised a machine-human hybrid approach to perform the classification task forVC types. Specifically, we have compiled a list of 49,187 VCs that made investments in China before 2021 from CVSource database, collected VC ownership information from other public sources, developed machine-learning algorithms to predict VC types, and used human coders when machine-learning failed to produce a prediction. Utilizing this hybrid approach, we have classified VCs into one of the following types: GVC (public agency-affliated, stateowned enterprise-affliated), CVC (corporate VC), IVC (independent VC), BVC (bank-affliated VC), FVC (financial/non-bank-affliated VC), UvC (university-affliated VC), and PenVC (pension-fund-affliated VC). We not only provide the most up-to-date database for VC types in the Chinese setting but also demonstrate how to leverage machine-learning algorithms to devise a transparent coding approach for VC-typeclassifications. ## Background & Summary Scholars have increasingly emphasized the importance of differentiating among various types of venture capitalists (VCs) such as independent VCs, corporate VCs, and governmental VCs, each with unique interests in the selection, investment, and fostering of ventures. For example, unlike independent VCs (IVCs) that focus on financial returns on investments, corporate VCs (CVCs) are mainly set up to capture technology windows or harness industry growth, thus prioritizing the strategic alignment between their parent firms and their investee ventures'. Governmental VCs (GVCs), demonstrating remarkable growth over the past two decades, are deemed an important policy tool for bridging the equity gap and supporting high-risk start-ups that would otherwise struggle to attract private capital2. Additionally, VCs might also have affiliations with other entities such as banks, financial institutions, universities, or pension funds, each with divergent objectives. Due to this heterogeneity in ownership, different VCs offer distinct value-added services, resources, and network access to their investee ventures and influence the ventures towards different exit channels3. It is thus of great importance to develop and continually update datasets that can facilitate research in this area, enhancing our understanding of the nuanced roles of various VCs in nurturing entrepreneurship and innovation. Despite the global proliferation of research on VC types4, there is an extreme dearth of such research in the context of China, the world's second-largest VC market, partly because of the scarcity of high-quality datasets differentiating among types of VCs. For example, as Dushnitsky and Yu (2022, p.1, p.4) argued, “most of what we know about CVC investors ... is based on data from the so-called developed world, and especially the United States and Western Europe” while “the Chinese setting can offer insights into different evolutionary paths" of CVC activities'. While the leading databases in China (e.g., CVSource, PEdata, and ITJuzi) have provided tags to annotate a few types of VCs (e.g., GVC, CVC), the tags are either incomplete or not up to the standard of research rigor. In an effort to mitigate this data limitation, Dushnitsky and $\mathrm{Y\bar{u}^{1}}$ have compiled a large dataset of CVCs in China by integrating multiple data sources; however, this proprietary dataset is not publicly accessible'. Similarly, prior studies on GVCs in China have manually collected and consolidated data regarding VCs? government ownership, but these datasets are typically reserved for private usage5,6. The first and sole study to have publicly disclosed data on VC types in China’s context is Chen et al.7. They manually developed a dataset categorizing 6,553 VCs according to their affiliations and made it freely available. However, this dataset only encompasses VCs active in China's market between 2000 and 2016, rendering it inadequate for analyzing the dramatic changes in VC activities in recent years. For instance, the influx of new VCs into China's market continued after 2016, resulting in a population of over 49,000 VCs as of 2021. Consequently, there remains a conspicuous absence of up-to-date, high-quality datasets delineating the types of VCs that have invested in China's market. More importantly, previous research on China's datasets has leaned heavily on manual coding, a laborious and time-consuming method1,5,6. They use public sources (e.g., WIND, China’s State Administration for Industry and Commerce, and $\boldsymbol{\mathrm{VCs}}$ websites) to discern the ownership of each VC. Such a manual approach suffers from low levels of transparency and is not able to conduct data/results triangulation. As Dushnitsky and Yu (2022, p.18) commented, “We point to an important issue associated with data availability in the Chinese setting. We find that CVC patterns based on data from one database are often not replicated when testing a similar specification using a different database? In other words, it is difficult to triangulate VC-type data from manually coded databases because of the inconsistency of their classification standards and low transparency. Machine-learning-based technologies allow the development of a more reliable, consistent, and transparent dataset. Recent advancements in machine-learning algorithms have showcased their superior capabilities in performing classification tasks8. Developing a customized algorithm for VC-type classification and making it open to the public would largely help researchers increase the effciency of data processing and the reliability of the findings. This is particularly pertinent given the exponential growth of VC numbers from thousands to tens of thousands in recent years, rendering manual coding nearly infeasible for completing the necessary tasks. Using a hybrid approach that combines machine-learning-based and manual coding techniques, we have developed a comprehensive dataset, termed ChinaVCtype, that classifies VC types based on their affliations as of 2021. Specifically, we assembled a list of VCs that had invested in China before the end of 2021, sourced from the CVSource database, a leading database on VC investment in China?. We then obtained their ownership details, such as shareholders, shareholder equity, and shareholder business scope, from public sources like Qichacha, a leading database on business administration information in China. In alignment with previous studies", we designed a multi-step process to categorize each VC into one of the following types: GVC which includes VCs affiliated with public agencies or state-owned enterprises, CVC, independent VC (IVC), bank-affiliated VC (BVC), financial/non-bank-affiliated VC (FVC), university-affliated VC (UVC), and pension-fund-affliated VC (Pen VC). The majority of this classification task is undertaken by machine-learning algorithm. If the algorithm can generate predictions, human coders are invited to double-check its coding quality. Whenever the algorithm is indecisive in predictions, we resort to human coders. A series of validation tests have been conducted by comparing the results of this newly developed dataset with prior studies, affirming its high quality. This study makes three important contributions. First, the dataset we have developed can foster a wide range of topics concerning VC types and entrepreneurship in the context of China. This includes concentrating on a specific VC type (e.g., GVC, CVC), comparing different VC types (e.g., GVC vs. CVC vs. IVC), and assessing the generalizability of VC analyses from developed countries to the Chinese setting. Second and more importantly, going beyond prior studies that struggle to triangulate VC-type data from multiple Chinese VC databases due to low transparency and low consistency of those databases? classification criteria, we have devised a machine-human hybrid approach that makes the VC-type classification process open, transparent, and consistent. By doing so, our study offers a unified VC-type data platform for future research to replicate, compare, and extend prior findings. Third, leveraging the machine-human hybrid approach, we not only provide a methodological foundation for future scholars to apply the data from various platforms on a large scale but also underscore the potential of machine-learning algorithms to assist scholars in performing extensive classification tasks. ### Methods Following prior literature, we develop our ChinaVCtype dataset by classifying VCs to seven types, including GVC (public agency-afiliated or SOE-affliated VC), CVC, IVC, BVC, FVC, UVC, and $P e n V C^{4,7}$ Weadopted prior studies' coding schemes whenever possible and made adaptation when necessary. We have developed machine learning algorithms to make predictions and invited human coders to conduct the classification tasks when machine learning algorithms failed to generate a prediction for a VC's type. The whole coding process is to be elaborated in the section“Data coding scheme?" Data collection. _ To generate a list of VCs, we started with the population of VCs that have invested in China's market as of 2021. In this study, we have adopted a broad definition of VC, referring to entities that make risky equity investments in entrepreneurial ventures. Consequently, the scope of VC in our study encompasses not only the narrowly defined VC but also private equity (PE), and even corporations that directly invest venture capital in ventures. This is because “a clear distinction between venture capital and private equity (PE) is lacking in China"9, and we have observed that many corporations may not yet have established their CVC entities to serve as an extension for their corporate venturing activities. Following this broad definition, in the CVSource database, there were 49,187 VCs that have made investments in China as of 2021, and the first deal appeared to be in 1978. Thus, we develop VC types for these 49,187 VCs in China’s market between 1978 and 2021. VCs basic information (e.g., VC name, age, location) was collected from CVSource. Information on VCs first-level shareholders (e.g., shareholder name, equity ratio) was collated from Qichacha's professional version (pro.qc.com). For those VCs that were not captured by Qichacha, we checked other public sources (e.g.,. Tianyancha, Bloomberg, Crunchbase, VC official websites, press releases, media reports) to gather information. If any inconsistency across sources was detected, we followed Bertoni and Marti10 to triangulate between multiple sources. ![](images/77fe832e0606e8cbfbf999f189484338dcd07d3a2011ea9c663a05ad7eb6c4d3.jpg) Fig. 1 Coding process. This figure shows the coding process to determine VC types. Data coding scheme. Figure 1 elucidates the coding process utilized to categorize various types of VCs. This process is bifurcated into two sections. Part I pertains to VCs possessing shareholder information such as first-level shareholder names and their respective equity in VCs. For these VCs, we formulated a method called "shareholder-based judgement?" This method initially employs machine learning or human coders to classify each shareholder's type. Subsequently, the shareholder's type and equity data are used to categorize the VC's type. Part II addresses VCs that lack shareholder information. For these VCs, we employed a method referred to as “direct judgement?" In this approach, machine learning or human coders are used to directly determine the specific category to which a VC belongs. Part I. Shareholder-based judgement. Based on the VC list from CVSource, we consolidated their full names and searched in Qichacha for their shareholder names, which resulted in 119,760 unique shareholders for 36,860 VCs. We collcted the basic information of shareholders (e.g., business scope, equity ratio) and developed a four-step (Steps 1.1-1.4) approach to determine VC types, as described below. Step 1.1 Consolidate shareholder information from Qichacha.We gathered basic information of VCs' shareholders from Qichacha, including shareholder names, registered capital, ranges of the number of employees, business categories, locations, business scope, introduction, and industries. This data included numerical, ordinal, discrete, and textual data, requiring different pre-processing techniques. We need to pre-process these various types of data to be recognized by machines. First, regarding numerical data (e.g., registered capital), we transformed them into ordinal data by using the tenth quantile as the range of classification. Second, as for ordinal and discrete data (e.g., ranges of the number of employees, business categories, locations, industries, registered capital transformed), we used one-hot encoding to transform them to be in the dummy formatl1. Third, considering the nature of Chinese context, we conducted multiple steps to pre-process textual data: We began with removing special symbols and unnecessary words (such as punctuation and messy code) and keeping Chinese characters, English characters, and numbers only. Next, we adopted the enterprise information dictionary and finance dictionary from Jieba (https://github.com/fxsjy/jieba), which is the most advanced word segmentation tool for Chinese, to segment words in each sentence, and applied stopwords lists from Harbin Institute of Technology to remove unimportant words or connectives12. After that, each shareholder's name, business scope, and introduction were processed by TF-IDF (Term Frequency-Inverse Document Frequency), a well-known weighting technique in information retrieval and text mining that can effectively measure the similarity between sentencesl3. Following the application of TF-IDF, each sentence was transformed into a vector. However, the high dimension of each vector poses a challenge for subsequent machine learning. To address this issue, we applied the low variance filtering method, which helps delete low-variance variables that have little influence on machine learning's prediction target. This method allows us to minimize the number of dimensions of the vectors and focus on key differences between each sentence. Step 1.2 Use supervised machine learning to predict shareholder types. According to previous studies, there are eight mutually exclusive types of shareholders: \*public agency, corporate, bank, financial, university, professional, person, and pension?"7 Machine learning is applied to differentiating among the first six types because they have plenty of textual information for algorithms to learn, while for person and pension we mainly applied human coders because it is faster to filter individual names by human coders and because China has very few pensionfunds. In addition, for a shareholder categorized as corporate, bank, financial, or professional types, it may have another level of label denoting whether it is state-owned enterprise (SOE)7. We also used machine learning to learn this feature and make prediction on the SOE label. Step 1.2.1 Sample split. The type of machine learning employed in this study is supervised machine learning. in which the algorithm first learns from a pre-labelled training dataset, predicts the labels of a test dataset, and is only applied to new data prediction if the prediction performance on the test dataset is deemed acceptable. In this sense, the training dataset is for a machine learning model to train its parameters, and the test dataset is to test the generalization ability of the model. To train the machine learning model, a sample with correctly labelled shareholder type (e.g. public agency, corporate, bank, fnancial, university, professonal, SOE) and feature information (e.g., shareholder names, registered capital, ranges of the number of employees, locations, business scope, introduction, and industries) is needed. For this purpose, we resorted to Chen et al's VCAC dataset7. They provided us the manually coded types of VCs' shareholders between 2000 and 2016, but they did not have shareholders feature information. To obtain the features for prediction, we searched in Qichacha using these shareholders names and obtained 6,404 unique shareholders with complete information. We divided these 6,404 shareholders into a training dataset and a test datasetas $80\%$ (5,123 shareholders) and $20\%$ (1,281 shareholders). Step 1.2.2 Model training. In total, we adopted six classical prediction models including Decision Tree, Random Forest, SVM, KNN, MLPClassifier, and Xgboost for prediction, using Python software. The metrics of prediction performance include precision, recall, and F1-score. Among the metrics, precision represents the percentage of how many positive cases predicted-to-be are with truly positive labels in the test datasetl4. In contrast, recall reflects how many truly positive cases have been recognized by the model as positive in the test datasetl4. F1-score synthesizes these two metrics and reflects the comprehensive performance of model prediction15. Thus, we used F1-score to illustrate the comparison of prediction performance. As shown in Table 1, Xgboost demonstrated superior predictive performance, with the highest accuracy consistently across all types. Thus, Xgboost model was used to predict shareholder types. The F1-score analysis of Xgboost reveals that Type 4 (Financial) records the lowest score, suggesting a low accuracy in predicting this type. A detailed manual investigation was carried out, revealing that the inadequate prediction performance is due to the resemblance in the text of Type 2 (Corporate), Type 4 (Financial), and Type 6 (Professional). As an illustration, suppose a shareholder's business scope contains “investment and engagement in industrial projects (投资兴办实业)” Because it mentions industrial projects, the shareholder should be categorized as Type 2 (Corporate). However, the term “investment" in the business scope may lead to the misclassification of the shareholder as Type 4 (Financial) or Type 6 (Professional). Another example would be, in the introduction of Type 6 (Professional) shareholders, terms such as “venture capitalist (风险投资)” and “business consulting (管理答询)” are frequently used, which also appear in the introduction of Type 4 (Financial) frms. To enhance the accuracy of the model's predictions, it is imperative to implement additional rules to differentiate between Type 2 (Corporate), Type 4 (Financial), and Type 6 (Professional). Step 1.3.1 Shareholder type coding. Consistent with Chen et al:s7 “coding on shareholder type", a two-step approach for shareholder-type coding was conducted. First, for each shareholder, we utilized its business scope information collected from Qichacha—and if this information was missing, we used information available from public sources-to categorize it into one of the eight mutually exclusive types: public agency, professional, corporate, bank, fnancial, university, person, and pension. The coding scheme is shown in Table 4. Second, for shareholders categorized as corporate, bank, financial, or professional types, we also assessed whether it is SOE. Specifically, we adhered to the procedure outlined by Chen et al.7 for “coding the SOE nature of shareholders.?7 We based our judgement of the SOE classification on two established documents they adopted, namely, “Measures for the Supervision and Administration of the Transactions of State-owned Assets of Enterprises (Order No. 32)” and “Measures for the Supervision and Administration of State-owned Equity of Listed Companies (Order No. 36):" Step 1.4 Use shareholders' type and equity ratio to code VC type. With the predicted/coded results on sharehoider type and the collected information about share ratio, we proceeded with VC-level type classification. Following prior literature', we created two modes of coding, namely, "non-exclusive VC type coding” and "'mutually exclusive VC type coding? This step was done by manual coding via Stata software. Non-exclusive VC type coding is to account for research needs drawing from theories that concern the diversity of shareholders (e.g., resource-based view, agency theory, institutional logics theory). For example, a VC can tap into a variety of resources if it has multiple types of shareholders or may face different pressures from different types of shareholders, such as a public agency, corporate, and bank. Consequently, a VC can be associated with multiple affiliations that together shape its investment strategies. The coding scheme for non-exclusive VC type coding is adopted from prior literature, as shown in Table 5. Mutually exclusive VC type coding is to accommodate research needs that concern the heterogeneity at VC level, such as the diversity of VCs in a syndicate. In this case, it would be better if a VC is affliated with a unique type, and every type is mutually exclusive. For this aim, we created a mutually exclusive coding scheme of VC type following prior literature7. The coding follows a sequential process, as shown in Table 6. Part I1. Direct judgement. After we found shareholder information for 36,860 VCs and classified their types based on shareholder information in Part I, we were left with 12,729 VCs that had no shareholder information on Qichacha. They could be individuals, VCs registered out of Mainland China, or VCs that had deregistered, thus lack of record in Qichacha. For VCs with missing shareholder information, we collected their own information from CVSource and developed a three-step (Steps 2.1-2.3) approach to determine their types, as described below. Step 2.1 Consolidate VC information from CVSource.We gathered each VC's basic information from CVSource, including VC names, business categories, investment rounds, locations, introduction, and industries. This data included ordinal, discrete, and textual data, requiring different pre-processing techniques. We pre-processed these various types of data for machine learning. First, regarding ordinal data (e.g., investment rounds), we transformed them into discrete data by using the tenth quantile as the range of classification. Second, as for ordinal and discrete data (e.g., locations, industries, registered capital transformed), we used one-hot encoding to transform them to be dummy variables. Third, we pre-processed textual data, similar to what we did to the textual data of shareholders: We kept Chinese or English characters and numbers only. Next, we adopted two dictionaries (i.e., enterprise information dictionary, finance dictionary) from Jieba to segment words and applied stopwords to remove unimportant words or connectives. After that, we used TF-IDF to process each VC's name and introduction, followed by low variance filtering to delete low-variance variables. After data pre-processing, we obtained the representation of textual data. Step 2.2 Use supervised machine learning to predict VC types. The machine learning algorithm is capable of predicting the type of a VC only for mutually exclusive VC type but struggles to generate predictions for non-exclusive VC type. This limitation arises from the difficulty faced by the algorithm in learning and predicting the various affliations a VC might have in the absence of shareholder information. Thus, we employed machine learning to implement a mutually exclusive coding scheme for VC types. Specifically, the machine identifies whether a VC falls under the categories of GVC, CVC, IVC, BVC, FVC, UVC, PenVC, or if it's unable to classify a VC into any category. Step 2.2.1 Sample split. This is the same name used in \*ChinaVCtype.csv?" 2. Alias: A string variable that denotes the alias name of a VC. A VC could have multiple alias names, each being listed in separate rows. ### TechnicalValidation To ensure the quality of the dataset, the following measures were implemented: Upon dataset composition: Matching VC names between multiple sources. One difficulty in developing our dataset is to match VC names among multiple sources (e.g, CVSource, Qichacha) when they adopt different forms of VC names. To start, we referred to CVSource's deal database and compiled an initial list of 49,589 VCs that have invested in China before the end of 2021; however, most VC names are abbreviated in CVSource's deal database. This presented a challenge in matching these names with their full versions and searching for their shareholder information in public sources. To address this challenge and ensure the accuracy of our VC full names, we employed a multi-step approach. First, because an organization's unified social credit ID (e.g., 91310000691612937 A, GP Capital Co., Ltd.) or its industrial and commercial registration number (e.g., 310000000096327, GP Capital Co., Ltd.) could be its unique identifier in China, we first applied these two pieces of information, if available in CVSource, to get VCs full names. Specifically, we collected VCs' unified social credit ID (e.g., 91310000691612937 A, Shanghai GP Capital) and full names from CVSource's GP (general partner) database, resulting in 13,767 VCs with such information. Second, in cases where CVSource's GP database did not contain this information, we used VCs' abbreviated names to search in Qichacha database. Specifically, we resorted to Qichacha's “firm name cleaning" function as a solution. This feature, available in Qichacha's professional version (pro.qcc.com), retrieves a firm's full name when an abbreviated name is submitted. We submitted all variations of VCs names recorded in CVSource (i.e., a VC's abbreviated name, its corresponding GP name, its corresponding LP name when it acts as a limited partner) to Qichacha's “frm name cleaning" function. A key advantage of Qichacha's “firm name cleaning? function is that it can provide a firm's full current name when an abbreviated or previous name is submitted. This step has led to the successful matching of 31,106 VC full names. We also collected their unified social credit ID or industrial and commercial registration number if available in Qichacha's “firm name cleaning? In total, the above two steps resulted in 44,873 full names of VCs, and there were 4,716 VCs that could not be matched with CVSource's GP or Qichacha databases using their names. Next, we conducted a comprehensive search in Qichacha database for the shareholder information of the 44,873 VCs using their full names. Our search revealed that out of these VCs, 36,860 had available shareholder information that covered 119,760 unique shareholders, and 8,013 VCs lacked shareholder information due to their status as either foreign or deregistered entities. For the 36,860 VCs with shareholder data, we categorized them following the shareholder-based judgement procedures outlined in Part I of Fig. 1. For the 8,0i3 VCs devoid of shareholder information, we directly determined their types following the direct judgement procedures given in Part II of Fig. 1. ![](images/7e7f735f4c14244b8ed19e26d12dc68100742eb269e82263f74027427af2680b.jpg) Fig. 2 The process of identifying VC full names. This figure provides a visual representation of the entire process involved in identifying the full names of VCs. Additionall, for the remaining 4,716 VCs that could not be matched with CVSource's GP or Qichacha databases using their names, we manually searched for their full names in public sources and directly classified them, again adhering to the procedures detailed in Part II of Fig. 1. In total, we classified 12,729 VCs directly without reliance on shareholder information. Upon acquiring the full names of VCs, we thoroughly consolidated the list. This process uncovered that a VC might have several different names within the CVSource dataset.For instance,“杭州阿里巴巴创业投资管理有 限公司”(Hangzhou Alibaba Venture Capital Management Co., Ltd.) and “阿里巴巴创投" (Alibaba VC) denote the same VC firm. After eliminating these duplicate instances, we compiled a definitive list of 49,187 unique VCs identified by their full names. In directly judging the types of 12,729 VCs, 5,506 were successfully categorized by machine learning algorithms, while the remaining 7,223 that did not have complete information necessary for machine learning required further manual classification by human coders. The human coders conducted a thorough review of public sources to ensure accuracy. To maintain quality control, we formed a four-person team consisting of two master students with relevant industry experience and two authors. The third author provided training and quality checks for student research assistants until they met our standards. The research assistants then classified the VCs, with the third author conducting a double-check of any inconsistent results. If disagreements persisted, the first author was consulted to resolve the issue and achieve a final decision. This rigorous process helps ensure the quality of human coding.
